title: License
text:
Unless otherwise noted, all content on this website—including text, graphics, logos, and design—is the intellectual property of the Pattern Institute. All rights reserved.
You may not copy, reproduce, distribute, transmit, display, or create derivative works from any content on this site without prior written permission from the Pattern Institute.
For inquiries regarding reuse, licensing, or academic citation, please contact us at email@pattern.institute.

Scientific software
Software developed by the Pattern Institute is released under its own license terms, which are specified in the corresponding source code repositories or documentation.
In general, we adopt permissive open-source licenses (such as MIT or Apache 2.0) that support transparency, reproducibility, and community reuse in scientific research. These licenses allow for modification and redistribution, provided the original license terms are respected.
We encourage contributions and collaboration, and our software is typically hosted on platforms such as GitHub for public access. For details on a specific project’s licensing terms, please refer to its individual repository.


Scientific data
Scientific datasets shared by the Pattern Institute are, unless otherwise stated, made available under open data principles, aligned with the FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) data standards.
Where possible, data is released under permissive licenses such as CC BY 4.0, which allow for reuse with appropriate attribution. Any restrictions due to ethical, privacy, or third-party agreements will be clearly documented in the associated metadata or landing pages.
Our goal is to advance open science by making high-quality research data accessible to the wider community, while maintaining responsible data stewardship.

title: Paulo Martel
text:
A Computational Biochemist / Bioinformatician with a particular focus on Molecular Modelling and Structural Biology.
Some might label him a computer geek, and they wouldn’t be far off. He finds joy in Python programming, working in the Linux operating system, and criticizing Windows.
Residing in the sunny city of Faro, he teaches at the University of Algarve, ensuring a consistent supply of Vitamin D throughout the year. Paulo also delights in playing the piano, biking, hiking, and solving Rubik’s cubes.

title: Tomás Pais de Azevedo
text:
I love Science, Microscopy, and Communication!
I am an Evo-Devo Biologist with a Ph.D. in Biomedical Sciences and specialized in microscopy.

title: Tomás Pais de Azevedo
text:
Science
In my research, I have been challenged to find solutions to scientific problems, including building a custom-made incubation chamber, learning ancient embryological techniques, or finding genes that regulate cell fate in development. And because I believe that science is made for the community, I was happily able to publish my own and my colleague’s results by authoring or co-authoring 7 scientific papers.

title: Tomás Pais de Azevedo
text:
Experience
In the last years, I have become manager of a Microscopy Unit, where I trained more than 60 researchers in using different microscopes. Here I had the pleasure of seeing the joy on their faces when seeing their results before their eyes and successfully immortalized in beautiful images.

title: Tomás Pais de Azevedo

I am an enthusiastic science communicator and I love exciting audiences with the wonders of my work in science, having received 2 conference talk awards for that. I have also taken great delight in organizing several meetings and symposiums, alone and part of a team, and participating in various outreach activities. In these especially, I never get tired of seeing the participant’s reactions of surprise and happiness with the science shown, irrespective of age and academic level.

title: Rui Peres dos Santos
text: After my Msc degree testing the effects of drugs administered to zebrafish on bone development, I pursued my life-long dream of working with cetaceans.

title: Rui Peres dos Santos
text:
Experience
Over the last 15 years, I have acquired field experience working on a daily basis as a skipper for whale watching companies in the Azores. While developing my boat handling and interpretation skills, I developed a protocol to collect cetacean data using these opportunistic observation platforms. The database I created over seven consecutive years contains more than 5500 cetacean sightings.

title: Rui Peres dos Santos
text:
PhD thesis
Currently I am earning a PhD at Restoration, Resources, Connectivity and Climate (R2C2), and Centre of Marine Sciences (CCMAR), from the University of the Algarve, Portugal and Mingan Island Cetacean Study (MICS), Canada for a thesis entitled Temporal and Spatial Distribution of Cetaceans in the Azores, as a means to define migration and dispersal patterns employing associated biotic and abiotic distributional driving factors. This will contribute significantly to improve cetacean habitat use knowledge in the Azores, as well as, in North Atlantic areas which are related to the Azores.

title: Rui Peres dos Santos

I also started in 2021 a Project entitled “Projecto Farol”, whose main objective is to estimate cetacean abundance in the Algarve region.

title: EMPHASIZE
text:
EMPHASIZE is the acronym for the research project titled “Exploring the Muscle Factors Predictive of Hepatic Function”, funded under the 2023 Exploratory Project Call for All Scientific Domains by the Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia (FCT). The project is led by Ana Luísa de Sousa Coelho at the University of Algarve (UAlg).
This project aims to identify key muscle-related biomarkers and to develop computational models that can predict hepatic function outcomes, particularly in the context of bariatric surgery. By integrating biomolecular data with advanced computational approaches, the project seeks to improve patient stratification and personalized treatment strategies.
The Pattern Institute (PI), represented by Ramiro Magno, is a key partner in the project, contributing specialized expertise in computational modeling and data integration. Additional collaboration is provided by the Centro Hospitalar Universitário do Algarve, EPE (ULSAlgarve), ensuring access to clinical data and patient cohorts necessary for translational validation.

title: MitoProfiles
text:
MitoProfiles is a research project focused on the characterization of the gene expression landscape in cancers originating from organs with inherently high metabolic rates. Funded by the Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia (FCT) under the Call Advanced Computing Projects (3rd ed.) - A0 Experimental Access (round C) program, the project is led by Isabel Duarte, a researcher at the University of Algarve and a member of the Pattern Institute.
The project aims to systematically analyze mitochondrial gene expression patterns across various cancer types, particularly those arising in metabolically active organs. By leveraging publicly available transcriptomic datasets and applying bioinformatics methodologies, MitoProfiles seeks to uncover distinct mitochondrial profiles that could offer new insights into cancer metabolism and potential therapeutic targets.

title: R for Absolute Beginners
text: In this self-paced tutorial, R4AB | Hands-on Tutorial, we introduce you to the basics of R programming—perfect for absolute beginners. We’ll cover essential topics like navigating R and RStudio, understanding R’s syntax, and working with fundamental data structures such as vectors, matrices, data frames, lists, and factors. You’ll also get a brief introduction to control-flow structures like loops and conditionals, learn how to write simple functions, and explore some of R’s most commonly used built-in functions. The tutorial is divided into seven manageable sections, each with clear objectives and hands-on exercises to reinforce your learning. By the end, you’ll have a solid foundation to start your journey in data analysis with R.

title: Partners
text: The Pattern Institute advances its mission through collaborations with a diverse network of partners spanning marine ecology, biomedical research, clinical trial reporting, bioinformatics, and neuroscience. We work alongside public universities, private research centers, international consortia, cooperatives, and industry leaders to tackle complex scientific and technological challenges. These partnerships strengthen our ability to connect fundamental research with real-world applications across health, the environment, and data science.

title: Pattern Institute
text:
Mission
The Pattern Institute is a nonprofit research organization dedicated to advancing scientific discovery, education, and outreach, with a particular emphasis on systems and complexity science. It applies mathematical and computational approaches to uncover patterns across the natural, formal, and social sciences.





Pattern Institute is an independent non-profit research institution located in Faro, Portugal.




Values
At the Pattern Institute, we are guided by a set of values that reflect both our scientific rigor and our creative spirit. We embrace a grassroots approach, where inclusivity, participation, and shared ownership are central to how we work. Our structure favors adhocracy—flexible, decentralized, and responsive—enabling collaboration to flourish in dynamic environments.
We promote scientific skepticism, challenging assumptions and fostering critical inquiry as a path to innovation. Through fractional scholarship, we support flexible academic engagement, welcoming researchers who contribute alongside other life and professional commitments.
Our commitment to open science ensures that knowledge is accessible, transparent, and collaborative. We celebrate polymathy by encouraging curiosity across disciplines, and value playfulness as a source of creativity, resilience, and intellectual joy.


Contact
The best way to reach us is by email: email@pattern.institute. Otherwise, feel free to contact any of the team members directly.

title: Getting involved
text:
This section highlights computational projects that are in early development or could benefit from additional input to reach their full potential. Whether you’re a student, researcher, or developer interested in contributing, we welcome collaborators to join us.
These projects offer opportunities to gain hands-on experience, share expertise, and co-author meaningful scientific tools.
By the way, we also welcome your own ideas.
Just drop us an email at email@pattern.institute if you’re interested.

title: Getting involved
text:
1 ensemblr
  
{ensemblr} is an R client to the Ensembl REST API.





ensemblr package: an R client to the Ensembl REST API.


The package currently covers only a subset of available endpoints. We are in the process of migrating its internals from the now-superseded httr package to the newer httr2. Ramiro Magno and Dany Mukesha are working on this, but the project would benefit from an extra pair of hands—especially if you’re interested in building API wrappers.
Browse the source code at https://github.com/patterninstitute/ensemblr.

title: Getting involved
text:
2 fluents
  
{fluents} is an R package that re-implements grind.R, originally developed by Rob de Boer. grind.R itself is a port of de Boer’s earlier C-based program, GRIND (GReat INtegrator Differential equations), designed for solving systems of differential equations.





The name fluents is inspired by Newton’s fluent concept, referring to any variable that changes over time.


The project was initiated by Ramiro Magno and is currently looking for contributors to help bring it to a publishable first release, ideally on CRAN. If you have an interest in dynamical systems, biology, and R programming, this could be an exciting project to get involved in.
Browse the source at https://github.com/ramiromagno/fluents.

title: Getting involved
text:
3 W4
  
{w4} is an R package that aims to bring the W4 method into R. The W4 method is an alternative to the Newton-Raphson (NR) method for nonlinear root finding. It offers a wider convergence region (Newton basin), though it converges linearly rather than quadratically, as the NR method does.
A proof of principle has been implemented, but the project would benefit from a more performant implementation, as well as improved testing and documentation. This may be a good fit for you if you enjoy numerical methods and programming in C or C++.
Browse the source at https://github.com/ramiromagno/w4.

title: Getting involved
text:
4 Fractional significant digits in R
  
We are looking for collaborators to help implement the methodology proposed by Jørgen L. Nikolajsen in his article Fractional Significant Digits (SIAM J. Sci. Comput., 2014) as an R package.
The paper introduces two methods for quantifying the number of significant digits (specifically, fractional significant digits, or FSDs) in approximate numerical results. This offers a finer and more nuanced metric of accuracy than traditional relative or absolute error—especially relevant when comparing the performance of iterative root-finding or eigenvalue algorithms.

title: Getting involved
section: 5 Stopping criteria for iterative root finding
text:
5 Stopping criteria for iterative root finding
  
We are seeking collaborators to develop an R package that implements the stopping criteria for iterative root-finding algorithms as proposed by Nikolajsen (2014). These criteria aim to enhance the efficiency of root-finding methods by terminating iterations immediately when no further improvement is possible, reducing computational workload without compromising accuracy.​
This project can be a follow-up on Project 4.

title: Getting involved
text:
6 GLFW bindings for R
  
We welcome collaborators to contribute to {glfw}, an experimental R package that provides bindings to the GLFW library—a lightweight framework for creating windows, contexts, and managing input in OpenGL-based applications.



This project enables R users to interact directly with the GLFW API, opening the door to interactive visualizations, real-time simulations, and even basic game development within the R ecosystem. While R is not typically used for graphics programming at this level, {glfw} explores what’s possible when low-level control meets high-level language flexibility.
If any of the following spark your interest, we’d love to collaborate:

You enjoy programming in C or tinkering with low-level code
You have experience (or want to gain some!) with OpenGL or graphics pipelines
You’re excited by the idea of making R more interactive and dynamic
You’re curious about systems programming, real-time rendering, or just trying something new

If you’re excited about expanding R’s capabilities into graphics and input systems—or just want to experiment with building high—performance graphical tools—explore the source at https://github.com/ramiromagno/glfw.

title: Getting involved
text:
7 plink2
  
{plink2} is an R package under development that aims to provide a high-level interface to PLINK 2, a widely used toolset for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and population genetics.
The goal of this project is to make PLINK 2 workflows more accessible and reproducible within R, allowing users to script, document, and share their analyses using familiar R syntax—while still benefiting from PLINK 2’s speed and efficiency.
What we’re building:

A lightweight R interface to PLINK 2 commands using system calls
Helpers to manage input/output paths and file formats
Functions that wrap common PLINK 2 workflows (e.g., filtering, association testing, PCA)
Structured outputs returned as tibbles or data frames for seamless integration with tidyverse tools

Who this might interest:

R users working with large-scale genomic data
Researchers looking to automate and document PLINK 2 pipelines
Contributors interested in building reproducible infrastructure for genetic analysis

The project is in an early stage, and we’re actively shaping its scope. If you’re familiar with PLINK or interested in bridging the gap between command-line tools and R, we’d love to hear from you.
Explore the repo at https://github.com/patterninstitute/plink2/.

title: Getting involved
text:
8 GWAS-SSF importer for R
  
We’re proposing a new project to create an R package that imports GWAS-SSF (Summary Statistics Format) files—an emerging standard for sharing genome-wide association study (GWAS) summary statistics.
The GWAS-SSF format aims to harmonize GWAS summary data across studies by defining a consistent, metadata-rich, tab-delimited format. This R package would help researchers read, validate, and analyze SSF-compliant datasets within R workflows.
What we aim to build:

A robust importer that reads .tsv files and associated metadata.yaml into structured R objects
Input validation and schema checking (e.g., required columns, field types, ontology term checks)
Support for tidy parsing of optional fields (e.g., imputation quality, allele frequency, standard error)
Optional integration with gwasrapidd or other tools for downstream querying and analysis
Utilities to coerce or export data into other formats (e.g., PLINK, VCF, or custom table layouts)

Who this might interest:

Researchers working with publicly available GWAS summary statistics
Developers building pipelines for polygenic risk scores or meta-analyses
Contributors interested in genomics data standards and R infrastructure

title: Getting involved
text:
9 RDES importer for R
  
We are seeking collaborators to help build an R package that imports and parses datasets conforming to the RDES specification, part of the RDML ecosystem for qPCR data exchange and analysis.
The RDES format provides a structured and interoperable way to share qPCR data, metadata, and analysis results. While tools exist for working with RDML files in other environments (e.g., RDML-Ninja), there is currently no R-native support for RDES. This package would fill that gap by providing clean, standards-compliant access to RDES files for downstream analysis, reproducibility, and reporting.
This project is currently in the planning phase. If you’re interested in bridging the gap between open data standards and R-based analysis, join us in shaping the direction of this tool.

title: Getting involved
text:
10 geisha
  
{geisha} is a dormant R package project aimed at providing programmatic access to the GEISHA database, a curated resource of gene expression patterns during avian embryonic development—particularly for Gallus gallus (chicken).
This project offers a unique opportunity to bridge developmental biology and data science, by enabling researchers and students to query, explore, and analyze gene expression data in a tidy, reproducible R workflow.

Why revive this?

The GEISHA database is a rich and underutilized resource for studying spatial and temporal gene expression
With growing interest in single-cell and developmental genomics, a modern interface to GEISHA data could enable comparative and integrative analyses
The project provides a meaningful entry point for students and early-career contributors interested in combining biology and computation



Project goals

Restore and modernize the original package structure
Implement functions to access and parse GEISHA gene expression data (HTML or API, if available)
Tidy the data for use in visualization, clustering, or integration with other genomic datasets
Provide educational examples for developmental biology students and data science learners



Who this might interest

Students curious about developmental biology and gene expression
R users interested in scientific data wrangling and web scraping
Contributors excited to revive and modernize a meaningful project with strong educational potential

The project is in a recovery phase—there’s scaffolding to build on, but it needs love, debugging, and design thinking to move forward. If you’re interested in bringing it back to life, we’d love to collaborate.
Explore the repo at https://github.com/ramiromagno/geisha and reach out to get involved.

title: Getting involved
text:
11 ggchick
  
{ggchick} is a proposed R package for visualizing early Gallus gallus (chick) embryo anatomical structures using ggplot2 and simple features, inspired by the excellent ggseg package for brain atlas visualization.
The aim is to create a flexible and extensible system for plotting developmental atlases across Hamburger-Hamilton stages, allowing researchers and educators to map gene expression, annotations, or experimental data onto chick embryo diagrams.

Why this matters?
Chick embryos are a classic model in developmental biology, but visual tools for summarizing and communicating spatial gene expression are still lacking. {ggchick} would fill this gap by providing:

Stage-specific anatomical outlines as simple feature geometries (sf)
Predefined ggplot-ready atlases for key Hamburger-Hamilton stages
Functions for mapping data (e.g. from {geisha}) onto anatomical regions
Color palettes, region metadata, and plotting helpers for publications and teaching



Project goals

Create or digitize embryo atlas outlines and region labels from open sources
Build R datasets with cleaned and stage-structured geometries
Develop ggplot2-based functions for customizable plotting
Explore linking with {geisha} data to create stage-aware expression maps



Who this might interest

Students and researchers in developmental biology or bioinformatics
R users interested in spatial data, simple features, or scientific visualization
Contributors excited by educational tools and data-driven graphics

This project is in concept phase, with a vision to evolve alongside Project 10 {geisha}. If you’re passionate about data visualization, anatomical mapping, or building tools for the life sciences, we’d love to collaborate.

title: Getting involved
text:
12 complyr
  
{complyr} is an R package in concept phase designed to bring structure, reusability, and transparency to compliance testing. It enables method developers and auditors to define gold-standard expectations and test code against them—using a consistent, testthat-powered grammar that integrates with R package development and CI workflows.

Given enough rules, all code conforms.

Many domains—especially in regulated research, clinical pipelines, scientific reproducibility, or teaching—require that code and methods conform to specific standards. {complyr} formalizes that need by allowing compliance logic to live in its own well-documented layer:

Auditor packages define the rules and reference implementations
Method packages declare compliance using roxygen tags (e.g., @comply auditor.test)
Compliance tests are reproducible, versionable, and CI-compatible

This decouples method implementation from evaluation criteria, allowing third-party validation, shared compliance standards, and better communication of expectations.
The project is actively evolving and welcomes contributions, feedback, and use cases from anyone interested in reproducibility, scientific software, or robust API behavior.
Explore the code at https://github.com/patterninstitute/complyr/ and join us in building better tools for trust and transparency in computation.

title: Getting involved
text:
13 qPCR simulator
  
Quantitative PCR (qPCR) is a core molecular biology technique for measuring gene expression and DNA/RNA quantification. Despite its ubiquity, many early-career researchers begin using qPCR without fully understanding how experimental design choices—such as cycle thresholds, primer efficiencies, or replicate structure—affect the data they will later be expected to analyze.
This proposal aims to create a qPCR simulation environment in R: a pair of R packages designed to help users explore and learn the qPCR workflow in silico. The first package will simulate qPCR experiments with configurable parameters and noise models, producing realistic datasets suitable for downstream analysis. The second package will offer a Shiny-based graphical interface that allows users to explore the same simulation workflows interactively, without writing code.
Rather than building a digital twin of a specific instrument, this platform will serve as a sandbox for training and planning—enabling researchers to ask “what if” questions, test normalization methods, and learn best practices before stepping into the lab. Simulation outputs will be fully compatible with existing qPCR analysis packages, encouraging integration into teaching pipelines and reproducible reporting frameworks.

title: Getting involved
text:
14 hyperreal
  
This is a concept project for bringing infinitesimals into R with hyperreal arithmetic.
Using the vctrs framework, create a new vector class that mimics nonstandard analysis, enabling intuitive derivatives, integrals, and simulations of dynamical systems using infinitesimal steps. This project bridges symbolic and numerical computation, offering hands-on experience in modern R programming, abstract algebra, and the foundations of calculus—all while building a tool that could transform how we teach and explore change in complex systems.

title: R-Mind
text: The R-Mind Workshop is a three-day, hands-on introduction to data analysis and visualization with R, designed to help you build confidence working with real-world data. On Day 1, we cover the basics—loading data, running descriptive stats, creating visualizations, and performing simple statistical tests like correlations and t-tests. On Day 3, we take a deeper dive into transcriptomics, guiding you through differential expression analysis using edgeR and DESeq2, with a focus on good practices and clear interpretation. Whether you’re new to R or want to sharpen your skills for research, this workshop offers a practical and supportive starting point.

title: Tidy Data & Visualisation with R
text: In this practical workshop, Tidy Data & Visualisation with R, we explore how to turn messy data into clean, structured formats ready for analysis and visualization—no prior experience with R required. Using the Tidyverse as our toolkit, we guide you through core concepts of data wrangling and help you create clear, compelling graphics with ggplot2. The workshop includes hands-on exercises and real research examples, and participants also had the option to bring their own data for personalized feedback on the final day. Whether you’re just starting out or want to sharpen your R skills, this workshop is a great place to build confidence with data.

title: Publication-Ready Graphs using R
text: In this hands-on workshop, Publication-Ready Graphs using R, we walk you through the essentials of crafting beautiful, publication-quality visualizations—no prior R experience needed. Together, we explore the basics of data cleaning, learn how to build clear and effective plots using ggplot2, and see how to combine multiple plots with the patchwork package. We also share some practical tips on what makes a graph work (and what to avoid). You get plenty of practice along the way, and by the end, you’ll be ready to share your data stories with confidence.

title: Training
text:
We run hands-on training sessions that help you get comfortable working with data—especially using R or Python. Whether you’re just getting started or diving into something more advanced like transcriptomics, our workshops are designed to be practical, approachable, and useful for real research.

title: CaCau (Model Testing)
text:
CaCau (Cancer Causality for Precision Oncology | Model Testing) represents the next step in the CaCau project series, focused on validating and testing computational models developed to elucidate causal mechanisms in cancer. This phase specifically aims to evaluate model performance and robustness using large-scale molecular datasets, further supporting precision oncology applications.
The project is funded under the Call for Advanced Computing Projects (5th edition): A2 Regular Access | Fast-track by the Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia (FCT). It is led by Isabel Duarte, researcher at the University of Algarve and member of the Pattern Institute.

title: CaCau (Phase 2)
text:
CaCau (Cancer Causality for Precision Oncology | Phase 2) is the continuation of the CaCau initiative, advancing the computational exploration of causal mechanisms in cancer with the goal of contributing to precision oncology strategies. Building upon the preparatory work established in Phase 1, this phase focuses on the large-scale analysis of molecular data, employing advanced computing resources to develop integrative models that can inform personalized cancer treatment approaches.
Funded by the Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia (FCT) under the Call for Advanced Computing Projects (4th edition): A2 Regular Access, the project is led by Isabel Duarte, researcher at the University of Algarve (UAlg) and member of the Pattern Institute.

title: CaCau (Phase 1)
text:
CaCau (Cancer Causality | Phase 1) is a computational research project dedicated to the exploration of causal mechanisms underlying cancer development. The project leverages advanced computing resources to conduct preparatory analyses and develop computational workflows aimed at uncovering biological pathways and molecular interactions implicated in cancer causality.
Funded by the Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia (FCT) under the Call for Advanced Computing Projects (3rd edition): A1 Preparatory or Development Access (Round D), CaCau is led by Isabel Duarte, a researcher at the University of Algarve (UAlg) and a member of the Pattern Institute.

title: Leonardo Silva
text:
I’m a passionate researcher captivated by the mysteries of the natural world.
My expertise encompasses diverse research projects in agriculture and regenerative medicine. I believe that our small individual contributions wield immense influence, shaping the continuous evolution of our world’s complex systems. That’s why my brain is constantly storming with thoughts about discovering sustainable and innovative solutions to enhance our lives.
In my downtime, I find joy in sports like tennis, padel, and running. These activities not only bring me happiness but also recharge my creative energy, fueling my passion for making a positive impact.

title: David Paleček
text:
Physicist by formation, scientist by soul. I practiced ultrafast laser physics for photosynthetic light-harvesting (Lund), photocatalytic water-splitting (Zurich) and organic optoelectronics (Cambridge). Recently I switched to imaging and image processing, even more recently to metagenomics.
I am passionate (or worried) about fostering tech transfer and community-driven innovation through hackathons and educational initiatives made in an open and inclusive way to help academia progress. When I can, I go climbing.

Python Club
I maintain a free and open community for Python programming and beyond. Our approach supports group and project-based learning to accommodate various levels of programming proficiency. In addition, I also provide teaching assistance as needed.
Check out the Python Club for more details.


Python for Life Sciences
Together with Paulo Martel, we introduce computational thinking using Python and lay the foundations of control flows with a focus on working with data, including loading, wrangling, visualising and analysing in an automated way. By the end of the week, you should be able to develop your own ideas independently.

GitHub: https://github.com/Py-ualg/2024-intro-course.

title: Ana Cristina Maia Fernandes
text: I am a PhD student at the University of Algarve, and I’ve always had a passion for the natural world and sciences. My journey in science is driven by my innate curiosity for nature and understanding the world around us.

title: Ana Cristina Maia Fernandes
text:
Exploring the wonders of Development
Within the vast space of science, my academic focus is currently on the field of developmental biology. During development, a single cell gives rise to a fully functional organism through many processes that need to occur coordinated in Time and Space. I am particularly driven towards how these processes are regulated with proper timing, as cells don’t possess clocks, unless they actually do…

title: Ana Cristina Maia Fernandes
text:
The significance of outreach
In addition to my academic pursuits, I value the importance of science outreach and bringing science and knowledge closer to communities. Knowledge is power, and combined with critical thinking these are very useful allies in navigating our world, where misinformation is spreading at alarming rates. This is one of the reasons I am very happy to be member of the Pattern Institute, which is also dedicated to making science more accessible to everyone.

title: Ana Cristina Maia Fernandes

A glimpse into my personal interests
I love to explore and learn new things, think and discuss ideas with my friends and peers. I love outdoor activities, particularly if those involve water. Exploring Japan, my current residence, has become one of my favorite pastimes. I also enjoy photography, even if my skill is questionable, particularly at sunset or night settings.

title: Isabel Duarte

title: Isabel Duarte
text:
Science
I use Computational Biology/Bioinformatics as a way of answering biologically relevant questions. I have used OMICs datasets to study the genetic regulation of cancer, early vertebrate embryo development, stem cell differentiation, and mitochondrial evolution.
Values | I value transparency, diplomacy, and openness. I am a strong believer in mutual respect and understanding. I advocate and apply reproducible and open research practices.

title: Isabel Duarte

Hobbies
I love to read, to play ukulele, to think, to learn and to teach, to discuss new ideas, and to engage in outdoors activities with my friends.
I regularly organize get-together evenings of relaxed scientific discussions or board game nights, over tea and homemade cake.
Others describe me as creative, curious, upbeat and reliable. I see myself as transparent.
